Award.AwardTitle: Unity of Purpose for Equitable Representation in Geosciences Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed Unity of Purpose for Equitable Representation in Geosciences Workshop is a convening of geoscience organizations, minority-serving professional organizations, minority-serving academic institutions, government agencies, and large facilities with an interest and capacity to positively effect change within their organizations around broadening participation efforts. The proposed workshop will support up to 40 attendees (national and local) and be held over two-days, January 2017 in Arlington, Virginia. Workshop participants will: 1) engage in focused discussions about broadening participation in geosciences academic programs and professions; 2) identify systemic or institutionalized barriers to inclusion in geosciences; 3) brainstorm methods to eliminate institutional barriers to inclusion, and 4) support development of a unified message to equitably represent diversity in geoscience disciplines nationwide that will be shared among participating organizations and institutions.

This workshop will bring to light strategies for increased communication, dialogue, and partnerships that are necessary to refine solutions to broadening participation efforts. Knowledge gained will identify approaches to attract increased participation of HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities) and TCU (Tribal Colleges and Universities) faculty and students in professional meetings, and better understand how professional associations can support MSIs (Minority-Serving Institutions). Traditionally earth science organizations have positively cooperated and pooled resources on projects of similar scale however they have not fully engaged in efforts with MSIs and minority-serving organizations in such an all-encompassing manner. By bringing together an assortment of professionals representing the geosciences and STEM that are committed to diversity, we hope to embolden a model with which minority and professional organizations can use to work together on broadening participation efforts. This workshop has the potential to offer comprehensive approach to support diversity and inclusivity efforts moving forward.

Institution.Name: The Geological Society of America, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA, INC., THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complexity of challenges facing humankind is growing and the need for skilled scientists to solve these issues with creativity and innovation is essential. Broadening the participation in STEM disciplines has become a critical approach for engaging diverse communities in science to increase experiences, perspectives, and innovative contributions to science. However, as the population of the United States continues to diversify, a proportionate rise of minority participation in the geosciences has not followed. Geoscientists, in particular, contend with issues that affect human communities worldwide such as energy, geologic hazards, minerals, waste disposal, and water, all elements critical to human safety and survival.

This project supported cohorts of faculty and students from Minority-Serving Institutions (MSI) from across the nation to attend the Geological Society of America (GSA) Annual Meeting, who would not have otherwise participated because of institutional financial constraints. The GSA Annual Meeting held each year draws 5,000+ professionals and consists of 4,000+ speakers, 200+ technical sessions, 20 short courses, and 30+ geoscientific field trips. It is the ideal geoscientific professional meeting to connect with others in the field.

The meeting was held in Indianapolis, Indiana, 4-7 November 2018 and each individual awarded submitted an abstract and presented their research at the meeting. The cohort consisted of 10 individuals representing 6 minority-serving institutions. Individuals in the cohort were seven undergraduate students, two graduate students, and one early career faculty member. The goal was to support groups who were presenting research results, therefore actively contributing to the scientific community and progressing professionally while representing diverse groups. Seven individuals were from underrepresented minority groups, three are first generation students, and one is a non-traditional student.

This funding helped increase the diversity of the GSA Annual Meeting by supporting students and one early career professional from diverse communities, which may lead to new collaborations and future research while contributing to the professional development of these participants. At the meeting the cohorts benefitted from taking advantage of all that a meeting of this magnitude offered including technical and poster sessions where current cutting-edge science research is presented, opportunities to network and build new collaborations, development of professional skills that will be critical to their own career trajectories, and better communication skills as they presented their own scientific work and unique perspectives.
